headline.main: U.S. Orders Health Labels On Cigars

docs.abstract: Federal government orders new health labels on cigar packages, requiring manufacturers to prominently display warnings about health risks and effects of second-hand smoke (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government today ordered new health labels on cigar packages, requiring manufacturers to prominently display warnings about health risks and the effects of second-hand smoke, a first for a tobacco product. Virtually every cigar package, box and advertisement will have the warnings as a result of a settlement between the Federal Trade Commission and seven companies that make the bulk of the cigars sold in the United States.

docs.abstract: People infected with AIDS virus in 1980's who are alive today have slowly watched threat of imminent death retreat and have been able to resume normal activities; antiviral drugs, mainly protease inhibitors introduced in mid-90's, have proven to be more effective than doctors and patients had dared to hope; drugs, while expensive, are widely available with aid of clinics and government subsidies; many people are still dying of AIDS complications; graphs; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: TO have lived with H.I.V. for a decade or more is to have died with it many times over. First came the assumption of imminent death, common to just about everyone who got the diagnosis before the mid-1990's. Wills were hastily written. Credit card debts ran up, and long-term plans were forgotten.
